classification.notes: Not FDA-approved for human therapeutic use; widely sold as research-grade peptide.

status.human_use_note: AOD-9604 is not approved for human therapeutic use. Despite this, it is widely marketed and consumed as a research peptide, particularly in weight-loss contexts. No regulatory body currently authorizes it for medical treatment.

structure.sequence_oneletter: Pep-Talk curation pending: we’re reviewing the evidence and will expand this section soon.
structure.molecular_formula: Pep-Talk curation pending: we’re reviewing the evidence and will expand this section soon.
structure.structure_image_url: Pep-Talk curation pending: we’re reviewing the evidence and will expand this section soon.

risk.rationale: Short-term human studies suggest limited adverse effects, but long-term safety data are sparse. The peptide mimics a fragment of human growth hormone, raising theoretical concerns around endocrine signaling, metabolic adaptation, and developmental exposure in adolescents.

overview.title: What it is
overview.text: AOD-9604 is a synthetic peptide derived from amino acids 176–191 of human growth hormone. It was developed to isolate the lipolytic (fat-metabolizing) effects of hGH without stimulating growth or insulin-like growth factor pathways.

use_cases.text: These are the most common real-world reasons people look into this peptide, plus the context that tends to matter most (quality, expectations, and safety).
use_cases.title: Use cases (real-world)

use_cases.text: fat-loss interest driven by early mechanistic claims
metabolic curiosity in wellness communities (evidence limited)
often discussed in weight-management stacking conversations (anecdotal)

observed_exposure_ranges.notes: Descriptive only. Observed in clinical studies; not instructions.

developmental_risk_block.text: Use during adolescence may interfere with normal endocrine signaling and metabolic regulation. Long-term developmental effects have not been studied and may be irreversible.

interaction_summary.text: Interactions here are category flags — they’re meant to help you ask better questions and avoid obvious conflicts. They are not a dosing guide.
interaction_summary.title: Interaction summary

interaction_summary.text: If you’re on cardiovascular, anticoagulant/antiplatelet, serotonergic, or immunomodulating meds/supplements, treat uncertainty as a reason to slow down and verify with a clinician.

current_outlook_bullets: a synthetic peptide derived from amino acids 176–191 of human growth hormone
it was developed to isolate the lipolytic (fat-metabolizing) effects of hGH without stimulating growth or insulin-like growth factor pathways
common biohacker curiosity due to community reports
interest in mechanisms suggested by early evidence
exploration in wellness communities despite evidence limits

evidence.title: A double-blind, placebo-controlled study of AOD-9604 for obesity
evidence.notes: Human trial evaluating weight-loss effects and safety over 12 weeks.

evidence.title: Lipolytic domain of human growth hormone
evidence.notes: Identified the 176–191 fragment responsible for fat metabolism signaling.

changelog.detail: Created first alphabetical peptide entry with human and mechanistic evidence.

practical.bottom_line: AOD-9604 is discussed for fat-loss and metabolic goals. Human outcomes are not well-established, so real-world expectations should be conservative.
benefits: fat-loss interest driven by early mechanistic claims
metabolic curiosity in wellness communities (evidence limited)
often discussed in weight-management stacking conversations (anecdotal)
side_effects_serious: chest pain, fainting, or severe shortness of breath
severe allergic reaction symptoms (hives, facial swelling, trouble breathing)
who_should_be_cautious: people with diabetes or unstable blood sugar control
people with cardiovascular disease or uncontrolled blood pressure
